isis.stitle: INSTRUMENTS - REMOVE AND INSTALL - INSTRUMENT CLUSTER COMPONENTS

svcprocinfo.para: It is recommended that the entire cluster be removed from the instrument panel to perform gauge removal and/or installation. This provides more work room and minimizes the risk of damaging the cluster or the instruments.

step1.para: With the cluster released from the instrument panel (refer to COMPLETE CLUSTER, Remove ), remove the three (3) bezel screws that fasten the bezel to the cluster housing, Figure 6. Place the instrument cluster face up on a clean, horizontal surface to prevent loss of unused gauge covers, gauges, etc.
Remove the bezel lens assembly from the housing and put it in a safe place to prevent scratching. Take care not to damage the gauge pointers with the bezel or lens , Figure 6.

All gauges with the exception of the Air Pressure, Oil Pressure, Hourmeter and Odometer are plug-in gauges. To remove, locate the hole in the back of the cluster behind the gauge and using a small, blunt tool such as a small screwdriver handle, push the gauge out of the housing. Once the gauge has cleared the retaining snaps it may be removed from the front.
The Speedometer and Tachometer are plug-in gauges and are removed as described in 3. above.

caution.para: After a gauge is removed from the cluster, it is important that the exposed pin terminals attached to the circuit board are not touched or shorted across. Static electricity or shorting between power and ground terminals can damage the cluster.

step1.para: To remove the Hourmeter and/or Odometer, disconnect the wiring plugs from the circuit board at the back of the cluster. At the front of the cluster, remove the adhesive-backed mask covering the gauge, then retract the two fingers that hold the gauges in the cluster and lift the gauge out of the cluster.

caution.para: When removing or in stalling the hourmeter or odometer, do not touch the metal portion of the leads that fasten to the circuit board. A static discharge could damage the cluster.

step1.para: Mechanical type air and oil gauges are front serviceable after the air and oil line fittings and the retaining nuts have been removed from the rear of each gauge.
Light bulbs are plug in type and are serviceable from the rear of the instrument cluster, Figure 7. The gauge back lights are #936 bulbs and the turn signals, high beam and warning lights are #37.

figure.caption: Removing the Bulb and Socket From the Rear of the Cluster

caution.para: Individual gauge dials are not protected by a lens. When removing or installing gauges, handle them by the edge of the dial face only. Do not touch the gauge pointer.
